test_query: Show me previous projects on medication reconciliation or reducing prescription errors using checklists or pharmacist review.
llm_output:
**Answer:** There are several relevant projects that focus on enhancing patient safety through the reduction of prescription errors and improving medication management. Here are the details:

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM054_SHP - Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In SengKang Polycli**
- Focuses on eliminating potential prescription errors in a polyclinic setting.
- Aims to enhance patient safety through improved prescription accuracy and error reduction.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM045_SCH - Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)**
- Seeks to reduce the medication incident rate within a community hospital.
- Includes strategies for minimizing errors during medication administration.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM012_SHP - Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly**
- Aims to improve the accuracy of medication prescriptions after a thorough review process.
- Focuses on reducing medication errors for patients following a detailed clinical assessment.

These projects highlight various initiatives aimed at improving patient safety through better prescription practices and error reduction strategies.

section: METHODOLOGY

Content:

   - Doctors did not change drug unit/frequency
   - Chronic medications not ordered in one set
   - Poor documentation (such as changes to chronic medications not indicated in prescription remarks)
   - Knowledge gap of doctors on drug doses.
3. title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
PDSA1: Standardizing medication charts on computer monitors in the consultation rooms. These medication charts provided information on acceptable doses of commonly prescribed medications. The charts also served as reminders for doctors to counter check all prescriptions and to order all chronic medications together in one prescription.

PDSA2: Bi-weekly PE data were emailed to doctors. Doctors with the highest error rate were identified and separately interviewed to find out the mitigating factors and how to prevent these errors from recurring.

PDSA3: Pharmacy technicians assisted to put aside prescriptions where changes to medications were not indicated in the remarks and/or chronic medications were not ordered together in one prescription. This would reduce error in drug omission for future visits.||CHUNK 4 || SECTION: OUTCOME || TITLE: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM054 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

section: OUTCOME

Content:
PDSA1: There was no improvement in the PE rate, possibly due to new doctors who joined the clinic during that period of time.
PDSA2: The PE rates improved to <0.05% by end of January 2021, from >0.08% in December 2020, though the effect was short-lived.

title: Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly

section: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS

Content:
An Ishikawa Diagram was used to analyze the cause and effect of medication errors. After a second round of voting, a Pareto chart was used to determine the top three causes (12 rule of voting).

Pareto Chart: Factors Contributing to Medications Error Post TBCU Review
- Nurses did not abide by the 6 RIGHTS when serving medications.
- Nurses were unfamiliar with Post TBCU review workflow.
- Nurses assigned to the service point after a period of time were unfamiliar to the workflow changes.||CHUNK 10 || SECTION: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS || TITLE: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM054 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: DISCUSSION

Content:
The findings indicate that while standardizing medication charts did not significantly reduce the prescription error rates (PDSA1), regular feedback and support for doctors (PDSA2) led to a short-term reduction in errors, but with sustainability issues. Long-term improvement was observed through continuous monitoring and assistance from pharmacy technicians (PDSA3).||CHUNK 14 || SECTION: CONCLUSION || TITLE: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM054 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

hospital: SHP
title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: CONCLUSION

Content:
Overall, the implementation of PDSA2 and PDSA3 achieved a significant improvement in the PE rate for Seng Kang Polyclinic. We suggest PDSA2 and PDSA3 be done monthly and to continue both interventions should it be ascertained that either or both interventions are useful in improving the PE rate with sustainability.||CHUNK 15 || SECTION: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM || TITLE: Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM012 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

title: Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly

section: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM

Content:
Between February and December 2021, there were a total of 4 medication errors in SingHealth Polyclinics related to post-TBCU review. Bukit Merah Polyclinic had 1 such medication error.

title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
1. Team members voted for what they felt were the most likely causes.
2. A Pareto chart was constructed and 5 leading causes were identified:
   - Doctors did not counter-check prescription
   - Doctors did not change drug unit/frequency
   - Chronic medications not ordered in one set
   - Poor documentation (such as changes to chronic medications not indicated in prescription remarks)
   - Knowledge gap of doctors on drug doses.
3. A series of 3 PDSA (Plan-Do-Study-Act) cycles were conducted from October 2020 to March 2021 to address these common causes.

title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
PDSA1: Standardizing medication charts on computer monitors in the consultation rooms. These medication charts provided information on acceptable doses of commonly prescribed medications. The charts also served as reminders for doctors to counter check all prescriptions and to order all chronic medications together in one prescription.

PDSA2: Bi-weekly PE data were emailed to doctors. Doctors with the highest error rate were identified and separately interviewed to find out the mitigating factors and how to prevent these errors from recurring.

PDSA3: Pharmacy technicians assisted to put aside prescriptions where changes to medications were not indicated in the remarks and/or chronic medications were not ordered together in one prescription. This would reduce error in drug omission for future visits.

section: OUTCOME

Content:
PDSA1: There was no improvement in the PE rate, possibly due to new doctors who joined the clinic during that period of time.
PDSA2: The PE rates improved to <0.05% by end of January 2021, from >0.08% in December 2020, though the effect was short-lived.
PDSA3: About 6 months into its implementation, PDSA3 saw an improvement in PE rate to 0.05% in August 2021, from ≥0.08% between February to July 2021.

section: RESULTS

Content:
PDSA1: There was no improvement in the PE rate, possibly due to new doctors who joined the clinic during that period of time.
PDSA2: The PE rates improved to <0.05% by end of January 2021, from >0.08% in December 2020, though the effect was short-lived. Many stable patients are seen at 6-monthly intervals by our doctors.
PDSA3: About 6 months into its implementation, PDSA3 (an intervention targeted at improving the PE rate in the longer term), saw an improvement in PE rate to 0.05% in August 2021, from ≥0.08% between February to July 2021.

Content:
Why is eliminating prescription errors crucial?
1. It poses a direct harm to patient’s health as it may result in potential serious adverse outcomes and compromise on patient’s safety.
2. Seng Kang Polyclinic (SKP) has a comparatively high rate of prescriptions errors (PE) amongst other SHPs.
3. From March to June 2020, SKP’s PE was mostly in the red zone (<0.07%).
4. By aiming to eliminate PE, we provide healthcare that is safe, timely, patient-centered, and efficient.

title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: DISCUSSION

Content:
The findings indicate that while standardizing medication charts did not significantly reduce the prescription error rates (PDSA1), regular feedback and support for doctors (PDSA2) led to a short-term reduction in errors, but with sustainability issues. Long-term improvement was observed through continuous monitoring and assistance from pharmacy technicians (PDSA3).

[section: CONCLUSION, project_code: SHM_RM054, year: 2022, hospital: SHP, relevance: 0.6] Metadata:

project_code: SHM_RM054
hospital: SHP
title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: CONCLUSION

Content:
Overall, the implementation of PDSA2 and PDSA3 achieved a significant improvement in the PE rate for Seng Kang Polyclinic. We suggest PDSA2 and PDSA3 be done monthly and to continue both interventions should it be ascertained that either or both interventions are useful in improving the PE rate with sustainability.

Between February and December 2021, there were a total of 4 medication errors in SingHealth Polyclinics related to post-TBCU review. Bukit Merah Polyclinic had 1 such medication error.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_PE035_SHHQ - Improve Patient Experience And Engage Patient Seamlessly Via Whatsapp Communication Channel**
- Project focuses on enhancing patient experience through seamless engagement.
- Utilizes WhatsApp as a primary communication tool for better interaction with patients.
- Aims to streamline and improve the quality of care delivery by leveraging modern communication channels.

No other projects related to engaging patients or caregivers using communication technologies like WhatsApp bots or SMS alerts were found in the provided context.

test_query: What methodology was used in successful projects that improved wait time perception at SKH Emergency Department?
llm_output:
The methodology used in the project "Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department" (SHM_PE023) included several initiatives aimed at improving patient and family member experiences, which likely contributed to better wait time perceptions. These initiatives involved structural and system enhancements such as an ED Patient Dashboard for real-time updates, SMS notifications for admission status, free-to-air TV entertainment, vending machines for refreshments, and reconfiguration of spaces for privacy.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_PE023 - Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department**
- Implemented structural enhancements such as an ED Patient Dashboard to provide near real-time updates on patient status.
- Enhanced the Supply Chain Management (SCM) system with a new column featuring flashing alerts for timely updates to Next of Kin (NOKs).
- Sent SMS notifications to update NOKs about admission statuses.
- Provided free-to-air TV entertainment and vending machines for hot/cold drinks and food to keep NOKs occupied during wait times.
- Reconfigured spaces, such as converting a grieving room into two separate areas to provide privacy and minimize interruptions.

These measures were designed to reduce stress and improve the overall experience of waiting family members, which can positively influence their perception of wait times.

year: 2022
section: RESULTS

Content:
Feedback from NOKs at ED regarding long waiting time as well as lack of information has decreased significantly from 27 cases in 2019 to 7 cases in 2021. MOH Patient Experience Survey data comparison between 2019 and 2021 showed improvement:
- Waiting Time To See Doctor (very reasonable/somewhat reasonable): 75.3% to 90.7%
- Empowerment & Care Transition (always, usually): 89.4% to 92.9%
- Willingness to Recommend (always, usually): 86.0% to 92.0%||CHUNK 3 || SECTION: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS || TITLE: Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_PE023 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

- ED Patient Dashboard to provide NOKs with near real-time update of patient’s status in ED
- SCM enhancement on new column with flashing alert to alert ED doctors/nurses to provide updates to NOKs at stipulated timing
- SMS to update NOK on the admission status of the ED Patients
- Free to air TV for entertainment to keep the NOKs occupied
- Hot and cold drinks/food vending machines

section: INTRODUCTION

Content:
Re-Imagining Sabrina Kee, Cecilia Pang, Dr Annitha D/O Annathurai, Sengkang General Hospital. Patient Experience (PE) team worked closely with Ops and ED to put structural and system enhancements in place in FY2020/FY2021 to improve on two main areas.
chunk_1:
[section: OUTCOME, project_code: SHM_PE023, year: 2022, hospital: SKH, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
source: SHM_PE023_SKH - Re-Imagining the Patient Experience at SKH Emergency Department.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:07:08.163419
project_code: SHM_PE023
hospital: SKH
title: Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department
year: 2022
section: OUTCOME

Content:
While perception of wait time has improved from 75.3% to 90.7%, the actual wait time at ED had actually remained the same. However, the waiting experience is deemed to be much better.
chunk_2:
[section: RESULTS, project_code: SHM_PE023, year: 2022, hospital: SKH, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
source: SHM_PE023_SKH - Re-Imagining the Patient Experience at SKH Emergency Department.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:07:08.163419
project_code: SHM_PE023
hospital: SKH
title: Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department
year: 2022
section: RESULTS

Content:
Feedback from NOKs at ED regarding long waiting time as well as lack of information has decreased significantly from 27 cases in 2019 to 7 cases in 2021. MOH Patient Experience Survey data comparison between 2019 and 2021 showed improvement:
- Waiting Time To See Doctor (very reasonable/somewhat reasonable): 75.3% to 90.7%
- Empowerment & Care Transition (always, usually): 89.4% to 92.9%
- Willingness to Recommend (always, usually): 86.0% to 92.0%

section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
The PE team worked closely with Ops and ED to put structural and system enhancements in place in FY2020/FY2021. Initiatives completed in 2021 include:
- ED Patient Dashboard to provide NOKs with near real-time update of patient’s status in ED
- SCM enhancement on new column with flashing alert to alert ED doctors/nurses to provide updates to NOKs at stipulated timing
- SMS to update NOK on the admission status of the ED Patients
- Free to air TV for entertainment to keep the NOKs occupied
- Hot and cold drinks/food vending machines
- Reconfigure grieving room into 2 separate areas to provide some privacy/minimise interruption for counseling of grieving NOKs as well as to keep the toilet/water dispenser available for both staff and NOKs
- Chairs with charging points to enable NOKs to use their mobile/laptop while waiting for updates

section: INTRODUCTION

Content:
Re-Imagining Sabrina Kee, Cecilia Pang, Dr Annitha D/O Annathurai, Sengkang General Hospital. Patient Experience (PE) team worked closely with Ops and ED to put structural and system enhancements in place in FY2020/FY2021 to improve on two main areas.

test_query: How did previous QIPs measure improvement in reducing inpatient falls due to toileting needs or ambulation support?
llm_output:
Previous Quality Improvement Projects (QIPs) measured improvement in reducing inpatient falls due to toileting needs and ambulation support through specific metrics and methodologies. For instance, SHM_RM001 at SKH reduced the fall rate related to toileting needs by 57%, from a baseline average of 0.63 to a current average of 0.27 falls per unit time.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM001_SKH - Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need
- Fall rate reduction of 57% related to toileting needs.
- Baseline average fall rate was 0.63, reduced to a current average of 0.27.
- No falls for five consecutive months before an incident in December 2020 due to decreased compliance.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
- Reported reduction in use of diapers by 67% and commodes by 93%.
- Increased ambulation frequency reported by 86% of nursing staff.
- No fall cases occurred during patient mobilization activities from April 2022 to March 2023.

test_query: What steps did successful QIPs take to implement multi-disciplinary interventions targeting medication error reduction?
llm_output:
Successful Quality Improvement Projects (QIPs) implemented multi-disciplinary interventions targeting medication error reduction through several key strategies:

1. **Formation of Multi-Disciplinary Teams**: Projects like SHM RM045 SCH and SHM_RM022 CGH formed workgroups that included pharmacists, nurses, physicians, and other healthcare professionals to address medication safety issues comprehensively.

2. **Regular Communication and Training Sessions**: These QIPs organized regular training sessions and communication channels (e.g., monthly bulletins) to ensure all team members were updated on best practices and new guidelines related to medication management.

3. **Development of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)**: Projects established clear SOPs for medication administration, review processes, and patient education to minimize errors.

4. **Patient Education**: Educating patients about their medications was a critical component in reducing errors. This included providing detailed information on drug usage, potential side effects, and the importance of adherence.

5. **Implementation of Visual Aids and Signage**: Some projects used visual aids like posters or signs to remind staff of important medication safety protocols at key points within the hospital environment.

6. **Regular Monitoring and Feedback Mechanisms**: Continuous monitoring through feedback loops helped identify areas for improvement and allowed teams to adjust their strategies accordingly.

7. **Collaboration with Community Partners**: Projects also extended beyond hospital walls by collaborating with community partners to ensure seamless transitions of care, which is crucial in maintaining medication safety outside the acute setting.

These steps collectively ensured a holistic approach to reducing medication errors through coordinated efforts across various disciplines and settings.

project_code: SHM_RM012
hospital: SHP
title: Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
### Goals:
1. To ensure all nurses utilize the checklist as a visual reference.
2. To reinforce nurses on checking the 6 Rights on every medication administration.

#### Intervention 1
A new checklist was created to include the patient's name, NRIC, review date, drug regimen, nurse's name and signature.

#### Intervention 2
Nurses provided comments on how to enhance the checklist. A new checklist was subsequently produced including items such as the patient's DOT registration number and the expected date of review return.

#### Intervention 3
A poll was conducted to assess the effectiveness of the treatment room checklist. To improve visibility and accountability, the listing items of the checklist were rearranged.||CHUNK 10 || SECTION: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES || TITLE: Zero Error || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: CGH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM022 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

title: Zero Error
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
Over a period of 2 weeks, training was conducted to all staff nurses who are involved in specimen collection, labelling and despatching using CGH policy on specimen collection.

New Visual Indicator:
1. Create a new visual indicator and remove unnecessary distraction such as photos and focus on what the important words.
2. Relocate the visual indicator to a more prominent and visible location designedly located for users to have contact with the indicator to create awareness, alertness, and prompt them to read and remind them to check the specimens.
3. To ensure the users do not miss the indicator, blinking light was added behind the visual indicator. These blinking lights are included to bring focus to the visual reminder.||CHUNK 11 || SECTION: OUTCOME || TITLE: Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM012 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

test_query: What metrics were used to evaluate the effectiveness of WhatsApp bot interventions for pre-surgical education?
llm_output:
The effectiveness of the WhatsApp bot intervention for pre-surgical education was evaluated using survey responses from patients, focusing on several key metrics:

- **Patient Reassurance and Anxiety Reduction:** 100% of respondents agreed that the project/bot helped to reassure them and reduced their level of anxiety.
- **Satisfaction with Information Delivery:** All respondents indicated they were happy with receiving information via the bot.
- **Time Efficiency:** The bot was found to save clarification time, reducing dwell time by approximately 10% during education counseling sessions.
- **Patient Recommendation:** Every respondent would recommend the bot to other patients.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_PE035_SHHQ - Improve Patient Experience and Engage Patient Seamlessly via WhatsApp Communication Channel
- The project aimed at improving patient experience through seamless engagement using a multi-lingual bot on WhatsApp.
- Feedback was collected from patients, indicating high satisfaction levels with the bot's ability to address frequently asked questions and concerns.
- Survey results showed that 100% of respondents found the bot reassuring and helpful in reducing anxiety.
- The project also demonstrated time efficiency by saving clarification time during counseling sessions.

test_query: How was success measured in reducing prescription errors in Seng Kang Polyclinic or near misses at Bedok Polyclinic?
llm_output:
Success in reducing prescription errors at Seng Kang Polyclinic and near misses at Bedok Polyclinic was measured through specific metrics and interventions as detailed below:

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM RM054 SHP - Enhancing patient safety by eliminating potential prescription errors in SengKang Polycli**
- Success was measured using the Potential Error (PE) rate, which improved from >0.08% to <0.05% after implementing PDSA2.
- The PE rate further improved to 0.05% with the implementation of PDSA3, indicating a sustained reduction in prescription errors.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM RM055 SHP - Implementation of Bin Code Location to Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses in Bedok Polyclinic**
- Success was measured by analyzing monthly near miss rates due to wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths.
- The near miss rate fell from 0.031% (July) to 0.029% (August), 0.019% (September), and 0.018% (October) after implementing the bin coding system in August 2021, indicating a significant reduction in near miss incidents.

Content:
The implementation of the bin coding system helped in reducing reliance on memory to locate correct medications, thereby minimizing near misses due to wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths during picking at SHP-Bedok pharmacy. This resulted in a noticeable improvement in error rates following its introduction.||CHUNK 2 || SECTION: RESULTS || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

year: 2022
section: RESULTS

Content:
Pharmacy monthly near misses rates due to wrong drug and dosage forms/strengths were analyzed from May 2021 to October 2021. The overall near miss rate improved after implementing the bin coding system in August 2021. Specifically:
- Near miss rate fell from 0.031% (Jul) to 0.029% (Aug), 0.019% (Sep), and 0.018% (Oct).
- Improvement was greater for wrong dosage forms/strengths compared to wrong drugs.||CHUNK 3 || SECTION: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

Content:

This reliance can result in errors when picking the wrong drug, dosage form, or strength due to lapses in memory.||CHUNK 4 || SECTION: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:19:43.686732
project_code: SHM_RM055
hospital: SHP
title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
A bin coding system was identified as a possible solution to reduce the picking of wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths. Each drug storage tray was assigned a unique bin address. A Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle was carried out from 1st August 2021 to 31st October 2021:
- Set up bin location in the planogram template.
- Pharmacy Technicians pick medications based on the bin code on each drug label.
- Collate and analyze near miss reports every month for three months.||CHUNK 14 || SECTION: BACKGROUND || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

project_code: SHM_RM055
hospital: SHP
title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: BACKGROUND

Content:
A near miss is an error or incident that is detected and prevented before reaching the patient. If such an error is undetected and goes to the patient, it may potentially lead to an adverse drug event and cause harm to the patient.

SHP-Bedok is a fast-paced primary care polyclinic with a high patient load. The number of pharmacy near misses had escalated in June and July 2021 compared to earlier months in the same year. These near misses occurred during the picking stage of the drug preparation process. Possible causes are high patient workload, constant interruptions, and staff fatigue.

Newly employed staff and relief staff from other polyclinics have difficulties locating and picking the medications due to drugs not being arranged according to their therapeutic indication in the pharmacy. In addition, staff who were familiar with the location of the drugs in the pharmacy tended to rely on memory to locate and pick medications to fill the prescriptions. However, mental fatigue could result in staff experiencing a lapse or slip in memory, thus picking the wrong drug, dosage form, or strength and resulting in an error.

The implementation of the bin coding system helped in reducing reliance on memory to locate correct medications, thereby minimizing near misses due to wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths during picking at SHP-Bedok pharmacy. This resulted in a noticeable improvement in error rates following its introduction.
chunk_2:
[section: RESULTS, project_code: SHM_RM055, year: 2022, hospital: SHP, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
source: SHM_RM055_SHP - Implementation of Bin Code Location to Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses in Bedok Polyclinic.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:19:43.686732
project_code: SHM_RM055
hospital: SHP
title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: RESULTS

Content:
Pharmacy monthly near misses rates due to wrong drug and dosage forms/strengths were analyzed from May 2021 to October 2021. The overall near miss rate improved after implementing the bin coding system in August 2021. Specifically:
- Near miss rate fell from 0.031% (Jul) to 0.029% (Aug), 0.019% (Sep), and 0.018% (Oct).
- Improvement was greater for wrong dosage forms/strengths compared to wrong drugs.

Content:
High patient load and interruptions contribute to staff fatigue, leading to reliance on memory rather than specific locations for medication. This reliance can result in errors when picking the wrong drug, dosage form, or strength due to lapses in memory.

project_code: SHM_RM055
hospital: SHP
title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
A bin coding system was identified as a possible solution to reduce the picking of wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths. Each drug storage tray was assigned a unique bin address. A Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle was carried out from 1st August 2021 to 31st October 2021:
- Set up bin location in the planogram template.
- Pharmacy Technicians pick medications based on the bin code on each drug label.
- Collate and analyze near miss reports every month for three months.

project_code: SHM_RM022
hospital: CGH
title: Zero Error
year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
Over a period of 2 weeks, training was conducted to all staff nurses who are involved in specimen collection, labelling and despatching using CGH policy on specimen collection.

Prior to training, 32 nurses were asked to evaluate their understanding of the guideline on specimen collection:
- 28 nurses were confident
- 2 nurses were somewhat sure on the Guideline
- 2 new nurses were unsure of the Guideline.

After the training, all the 32 nurses were able to articulate the correct process as per CGH guidelines.

New Visual Indicator:
1. Create a new visual indicator and remove unnecessary distraction such as photos and focus on what the important words.
2. Relocate the visual indicator to a more prominent and visible location designedly located for users to have contact with the indicator to create awareness, alertness, and prompt them to read and remind them to check the specimens.
3. To ensure the users do not miss the indicator, blinking light was added behind the visual indicator. These blinking lights are included to bring focus to the visual reminder.||CHUNK 3 || SECTION: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES || TITLE: Zero Error || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: CGH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM022 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

test_query: How did staff surveys reflect the success of medication checklists or mobility signage interventions?
llm_output:
Staff surveys reflected the success of both medication checklists and mobility signage interventions. For medication checklists, an online survey indicated that they helped staff be more focused and efficient during medication administration, with no reported medication errors among post-TBCU reviewed patients. Regarding mobility signage, 67% of nursing staff reported a reduction in the use of diapers, 93% reported a decrease in commode usage, and 86% noted an increase in patient ambulation.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM012_SHP - Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly
- Staff surveys indicated that the medication checklists helped them be more focused and efficient during medication administration.
- No reported medication errors among post-TBCU reviewed patients.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
- 67% of nursing staff reported a reduction in the use of diapers.
- 93% reported a decrease in commode usage.
- 86% noted an increase in patient ambulation.

Content:
The project team brainstormed and came out with the following interventions:
1. A medication safety workgroup was formed to look into all medication safety related issues. Incidents were discussed with root cause analysis, and corrective actions were proposed at workgroup level.
2. SCH monthly medication safety bulletin has been published to share best practices and correct procedures to ensure medication safety.
3. Medication safety vest was piloted in selected OCH wards with the aim to reduce disruptions during medication administration. The intervention was not implemented due to unsatisfactory pilot results.
4. To implement a “status board” in SCM as a “live” board to keep staff updated on the list of tasks for patients.
5. Medication safety champions at each ward were identified to further reduce the risk of medication incidents. The champions will reinforce correct procedures to ground staff and create awareness. At the same time, they will communicate with their colleagues on new medication practices if any.
6. Content:
### Goals:
1. To ensure all nurses utilize the checklist as a visual reference.
2. To reinforce nurses on checking the 6 Rights on every medication administration.

#### Intervention 1
A new checklist was created to include the patient's name, NRIC, review date, drug regimen, nurse's name and signature.

#### Intervention 2
Nurses provided comments on how to enhance the checklist. A new checklist was subsequently produced including items such as the patient's DOT registration number and the expected date of review return.

#### Intervention 3
A poll was conducted to assess the effectiveness of the treatment room checklist. To improve visibility and accountability, the listing items of the checklist were rearranged.||CHUNK 8 || SECTION: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES || TITLE: Reduce Medication Rate At Skch To Below 0.3 Per 1000 Patient Days (Ch Average) Over 1Yr || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM053 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:17:42.230879
project_code: SHM_RM053
hospital: SCH
title: Reduce Medication Rate At Skch To Below 0.3 Per 1000 Patient Days (Ch Average) Over 1Yr
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
1. In reducing omission due to medications stock not available in SKCH or SKH pharmacy, the ward pharmacy and nursing team will perform handover to account for the number of medications left in the patient’s medication box.
2. Alps team will check expiry date of ward stock every month and expiring items are removed 3 months prior to expiry for safety purpose.
3. Wrong supply from formulary was addressed by implementing non alphabetical bin location at pharmacy.
4. Auto-perfection function in SCM was disabled to prevent system auto select lowest dose for verification which lead to downstream wrong labelling of patients own medications.
5. Nursing-in house training modules established to train nursing staff on medication management.
6. Sharing of medication incident with learning points to all staff via monthly bulletin.
7. The use of medication vest was also piloted in the ward.
8. Medication safety champions at each ward were identified and they will reinforce correct practices to ground staff and create awareness.
9. Complicated medications scheduling in SCM is done by medical, which will then be verified by pharmacist prior to nursing administration.||CHUNK 9 || SECTION: RESULTS || TITLE: Adapting Cloud Based Platform For Real Time Updates || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_OP022 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

test_query: How was a bin code system implemented to reduce near misses during drug picking in Bedok Polyclinic?
llm_output:
A bin coding system was implemented at Bedok Polyclinic to reduce pharmacy near misses by assigning each drug storage tray a unique address. This involved setting up bin locations within the Pharmacy System and conducting a Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle from August 1, 2021, to October 31, 2021.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM055_SHP - Implementation of Bin Code Location to Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses in Bedok Polyclinic
- A bin coding system was implemented where each drug storage tray had a unique address.
- Placement of fast-moving drugs was reviewed for efficient and accurate picking.
- A PDSA cycle was carried out from August 1, 2021, to October 31, 2021, involving setting up bin locations in the Pharmacy System, pharmacy technicians picking medications based on bin codes, and analyzing near miss reports monthly.

processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:19:43.686732
project_code: SHM_RM055
hospital: SHP
title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
A bin coding system was identified as a possible solution to reduce the picking of wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths. Each drug storage tray was assigned a unique bin address. A Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle was carried out from 1st August 2021 to 31st October 2021:
- Set up bin location in the planogram template.
- Pharmacy Technicians pick medications based on the bin code on each drug label.
- Collate and analyze near miss reports every month for three months.||CHUNK 5 || SECTION: RESULTS || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.9 || CONTENT: Metadata:
source: SHM_RM055_SHP - Implementation of Bin Code Location to Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses in Bedok Polyclinic.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:19:43.686732
project_code: SHM_RM055
hospital: SHP
title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: RESULTS

Content:
Pharmacy monthly near misses rates due to wrong drug and dosage forms/strengths were analyzed from May 2021 to October 2021. The overall near miss rate improved after implementing the bin coding system in August 2021. Specifically:
- Near miss rate fell from 0.031% (Jul) to 0.029% (Aug), 0.019% (Sep), and 0.018% (Oct).
- Improvement was greater for wrong dosage forms/strengths compared to wrong drugs.||CHUNK 6 || SECTION: INTRODUCTION || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

section: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM

source: SHM_RM055_SHP - Implementation of Bin Code Location to Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses in Bedok Polyclinic.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:19:43.686732
project_code: SHM_RM055
hospital: SHP
title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: BACKGROUND

Content:
A near miss is an error or incident that is detected and prevented before reaching the patient. If such an error is undetected and goes to the patient, it may potentially lead to an adverse drug event and cause harm to the patient.

SHP-Bedok is a fast-paced primary care polyclinic with a high patient load. The number of pharmacy near misses had escalated in June and July 2021 compared to earlier months in the same year. These near misses occurred during the picking stage of the drug preparation process. Possible causes are high patient workload, constant interruptions, and staff fatigue.

Newly employed staff and relief staff from other polyclinics have difficulties locating and picking the medications due to drugs not being arranged according to their therapeutic indication in the pharmacy. In addition, staff who were familiar with the location of the drugs in the pharmacy tended to rely on memory to locate and pick medications to fill the prescriptions. However, mental fatigue could result in staff experiencing a lapse or slip in memory, thus picking the wrong drug, dosage form, or strength and resulting in an error.

chunk_4:
[section: METHODOLOGY, project_code: SHM_RM055, year: 2022, hospital: SHP, relevance: 0.9] Metadata:
source: SHM_RM055_SHP - Implementation of Bin Code Location to Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses in Bedok Polyclinic.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:19:43.686732
project_code: SHM_RM055
hospital: SHP
title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
A bin coding system was identified as a possible solution to reduce the picking of wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths. Each drug storage tray was assigned a unique bin address. A Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle was carried out from 1st August 2021 to 31st October 2021:
- Set up bin location in the planogram template.
- Pharmacy Technicians pick medications based on the bin code on each drug label.
- Collate and analyze near miss reports every month for three months.
chunk_5:
[section: RESULTS, project_code: SHM_RM055, year: 2022, hospital: SHP, relevance: 0.9] Metadata:
source: SHM_RM055_SHP - Implementation of Bin Code Location to Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses in Bedok Polyclinic.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:19:43.686732
project_code: SHM_RM055
hospital: SHP
title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: RESULTS

Content:
Pharmacy monthly near misses rates due to wrong drug and dosage forms/strengths were analyzed from May 2021 to October 2021. The overall near miss rate improved after implementing the bin coding system in August 2021. Specifically:
- Near miss rate fell from 0.031% (Jul) to 0.029% (Aug), 0.019% (Sep), and 0.018% (Oct).
- Improvement was greater for wrong dosage forms/strengths compared to wrong drugs.

section: INTRODUCTION

Content:
This document describes the implementation of a bin coding system at SHP-Bedok Polyclinic's pharmacy as part of efforts to reduce near misses. Near misses are errors detected before they reach patients and can potentially lead to adverse events if not caught.

section: DISCUSSION

Content:
Despite improvements post-implementation, some challenges persisted such as staff misreading the bin code or relying on muscle memory instead of specific locations for drug retrieval. These could be due to close proximity between similar-looking medications that were changed in brand or packaging.

section: SUSTAINABILITY AND SPREAD

Content:
For long-term sustainability, ongoing training and reinforcement on the use of bin codes are necessary. Adjustments can continue based on staff feedback and regular review of medication placement. The success of this intervention could be spread to other clinics facing similar issues.

test_query: What metrics were commonly used to evaluate fall prevention interventions?
llm_output:
**Answer:** The common metric used to evaluate fall prevention interventions is the fall rate per 1,000 patient days. This metric was used in multiple projects to measure the effectiveness of interventions aimed at reducing falls.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM052 - Reduce Fall Rate Of All Patients At Skch To Less Than 0.99 Patient Fall Per 1000Patients
- The project aimed to reduce fall rates across SKCH.
- Interventions were piloted in high-risk wards and then scaled up hospital-wide.
- Fall rate was reduced from an initial unspecified value to 0.69 per 1,000 patient days.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM044 - Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och
- The project focused on reducing falls at OCH.
- Fall rates were measured and reported as the number of falls per 1,000 patient days.
- The fall rate was reduced to 0.80 per 1,000 patient days during the specified period.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_CO005 - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
- This project did not focus on a numerical fall rate metric but rather on qualitative improvements in patient mobilization and use of assistive devices.
- Metrics included reductions in the use of diapers, commodes, and increases in ambulation frequency.

Content:
1. Established high fall wards for patients with high risk of falling.
2. Fall prevention brochures were printed for distribution to Next of Kin (NOK) in all wards.
3. The rehab team created A3 mobility board and abbreviation form to guide the nursing staff on patient’s mobility status.
4. The medical team conducted postural blood pressure assessment for new admissions.
5. Fall prevention script and education for patient and NOK was established.
6. Nursing grand fall rounds helped to educate staff on fall prevention measures in a timely manner.
7. Fall champions appointed in the wards helped to strengthen the fall prevalence efforts by the nurses.
8. Rehab team established fall Prevention Booklet/Guide for patient/NOK.
9. The walk steady award was implemented to recognize ward with zero falls on that month. The ward with zero falls for consecutive 3 months would receive Walk Steady CEO Fall Free Award.
10. project_code: SHM_RM052
hospital: SCH
title: Reduce Fall Rate Of All Patients At Skch To Less Than 0.99 Patient Fall Per 1000Patients
year: 2022
section: BACKGROUND

Content:
SKCH fall rate was 1.27 per 1000 patient days (Jul 19 - Jun 20) which was above CH average of 0.9 per 1000 patient days. Being a community hospital, SKCH team faced challenges in managing patients with cognitive impairment or post stroke conditions. Hence, the standard fall prevention measures may not be applicable for these group of patients. The management team has requested for QI project to be conducted to establish appropriate interventions to reduce fall rates in SKCH within a year.

test_query: How was patient or staff feedback quantitatively measured in successful QIPs?
llm_output:
Patient or staff feedback was quantitatively measured through various methods across different Quality Improvement Projects (QIPs):

- **SHM_PE023_SKH - Re-Imagining the Patient Experience at SKH Emergency Department**: Feedback from Next of Kin (NOK) regarding waiting times and lack of information decreased significantly, from 27 cases in 2019 to 7 cases in 2021. Additionally, MOH Patient Experience Survey data showed improvements: Waiting Time To See Doctor improved from 75.3% to 90.7%, Empowerment & Care Transition from 89.4% to 92.9%, and Willingness to Recommend from 86.0% to 92.0%.

- **SHM_PE035_SHHQ - Improve Patient Experience and Engage Patient Seamlessly via WhatsApp Communication Channel**: A survey was conducted where 100% of respondents agreed that the project/bot helped reassure them, reduced anxiety levels, provided useful information, saved clarification time (reducing dwell time by ~10%), and they would recommend it to other patients.

- **SHM_PE051_NCCS - Patient Acceptability N Satisfaction**: The study surveyed 59 programme recipients from October 2020 to April 2022. Participants rated the distress screening frequency as appropriate, found it useful for their care, and had an overall satisfaction score of 7.8 on a scale where higher indicates greater satisfaction.

- **SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization in a Pilot Ward to Reduce Patient Falls**: Monthly follow-up surveys were conducted by ward staff and nursing students from October 2022 to December 2022, collecting patient fall statistics during the pilot study period.

test_query: How did they define success in patient engagement initiatives.
llm_output:
Success in patient engagement initiatives was defined by gaining insights from patients and caregivers, soliciting feedback on the solution while making it relevant to their needs, and addressing frequently asked questions and concerns through a multi-lingual bot via WhatsApp.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_PE035_SHHQ - Improve Patient Experience and Engage Patient Seamlessly via WhatsApp Communication Channel
- The project aimed at improving patient experience by engaging them seamlessly.
- Feedback was actively solicited from patients to make the solution relevant.
- A multi-lingual bot on WhatsApp addressed frequently asked questions and concerns, enhancing patient engagement.

test_query: What indicators were used to assess medication safety in community hospitals or polyclinics?
llm_output:
Indicators used to assess medication safety in community hospitals or polyclinics include the rate of prescription errors and the incidence rate of medication-related incidents. Specifically, these are measured as:

- Prescription error (PE) rates: The frequency of prescription errors per unit time.
- Medication incident rate: The number of medication-related incidents per 1000 patient days.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM054_SHP - Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In SengKang Polycli**
- Project aimed at reducing the prescription error (PE) rate.
- PE rates were monitored from March to June 2020, with SKP's PE mostly in the red zone (<0.07%).
- The project used a Pareto chart to identify and address the top five causes of prescription errors.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM045_SCH - Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)**
- Project focused on reducing the medication incident rate.
- Monthly medication safety bulletins were published to share best practices and correct procedures for ensuring medication safety.
- The project team identified root causes such as lack of awareness, improper handover between nurses, and staff knowledge gaps regarding certain medications.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM012_SHP - Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly**
- Project aimed at improving the rate of medication errors for patients post-TBCU review.
- An Ishikawa Diagram was used to analyze causes and effects, followed by a Pareto chart to determine top three causes.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM053_SCH - Reduce Medication Rate At Skch To Below 0.3 Per 1000 Patient Days (Ch Average) Over 1Yr**
- Project aimed at reducing the medication rate to below 0.3 per 1000 patient days.
- Various interventions were implemented, including collaboration between medical, nursing, and pharmacy teams, and establishing training modules for nurses-in-house.
- Root causes identified included staff not adhering to medication safety policies, interruptions during administration of medications, and knowledge deficits among staff regarding new orders.

project_code: SHM_RM054
hospital: SHP
title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: DISCUSSION

Content:
The findings indicate that while standardizing medication charts did not significantly reduce the prescription error rates (PDSA1), regular feedback and support for doctors (PDSA2) led to a short-term reduction in errors, but with sustainability issues. Long-term improvement was observed through continuous monitoring and assistance from pharmacy technicians (PDSA3).||CHUNK 2 || SECTION: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES || TITLE: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och) || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM045 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:
source: SHM_RM045_SCH - Reducing medication incident rate in Outram Community Hospital (OCH).pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:15:06.467446
project_code: SHM_RM045
hospital: SCH
title: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The project team brainstormed and came out with the following interventions:
1. A medication safety workgroup was formed to look into all medication safety related issues. Incidents were discussed with root cause analysis, and corrective actions were proposed at workgroup level.
2. SCH monthly medication safety bulletin has been published to share best practices and correct procedures to ensure medication safety.
3. Medication safety vest was piloted in selected OCH wards with the aim to reduce disruptions during medication administration. The intervention was not implemented due to unsatisfactory pilot results.
4. To implement a “status board” in SCM as a “live” board to keep staff updated on the list of tasks for patients.
5. Medication safety champions at each ward were identified to further reduce the risk of medication incidents. The champions will reinforce correct procedures to ground staff and create awareness. At the same time, they will communicate with their colleagues on new medication practices if any.
6. Complicated medications scheduling in SCM will be scheduled by the medical team, which will then be verified by pharmacists prior to nursing administration.||CHUNK 3 || SECTION: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS || TITLE: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och) || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM045 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

[section: DISCUSSION, project_code: SHM_RM054, year: 2022, hospital: SHP, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
source: SHM_RM054_SHP - Enhancing patient safety by eliminating potential prescription errors in SengKang Polycli.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:18:47.684810
project_code: SHM_RM054
hospital: SHP
title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: DISCUSSION

Content:
The findings indicate that while standardizing medication charts did not significantly reduce the prescription error rates (PDSA1), regular feedback and support for doctors (PDSA2) led to a short-term reduction in errors, but with sustainability issues. Long-term improvement was observed through continuous monitoring and assistance from pharmacy technicians (PDSA3).
chunk_2:
[section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES, project_code: SHM_RM045, year: 2022, hospital: SCH, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
source: SHM_RM045_SCH - Reducing medication incident rate in Outram Community Hospital (OCH).pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:15:06.467446
project_code: SHM_RM045
hospital: SCH
title: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The project team brainstormed and came out with the following interventions:
1. A medication safety workgroup was formed to look into all medication safety related issues. Incidents were discussed with root cause analysis, and corrective actions were proposed at workgroup level.
2. SCH monthly medication safety bulletin has been published to share best practices and correct procedures to ensure medication safety.
3. Medication safety vest was piloted in selected OCH wards with the aim to reduce disruptions during medication administration. The intervention was not implemented due to unsatisfactory pilot results.
4. To implement a “status board” in SCM as a “live” board to keep staff updated on the list of tasks for patients.
5. Medication safety champions at each ward were identified to further reduce the risk of medication incidents. The champions will reinforce correct procedures to ground staff and create awareness. At the same time, they will communicate with their colleagues on new medication practices if any.
6. Complicated medications scheduling in SCM will be scheduled by the medical team, which will then be verified by pharmacists prior to nursing administration.
chunk_3:
[section: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS, project_code: SHM_RM045, year: 2022, hospital: SCH, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
source: SHM_RM045_SCH - Reducing medication incident rate in Outram Community Hospital (OCH).pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:15:06.467446
project_code: SHM_RM045
hospital: SCH
title: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
year: 2022
section: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS

Content:
Root Causes of Medication Events

| Root Cause                         | Percentage |
|------------------------------------|------------|
| Lack of awareness on medication safety        | 15%       |
| No / lack of proper handover practices during verification of medication order  | 13%      |
| Staff lack of knowledge             | 80%         |
| Lack of training or work instruction            | -          |
| Lack of system prompt               | -           |
| Insufficient guidance in cubicle (early morning)   | -        |

project_code: SHM_RM012
hospital: SHP
title: Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly
year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
The project started in February 2021. An Ishikawa Diagram was used to analyze the cause and effect of medication errors. After a second round of voting, a Pareto chart was used to determine the top three causes (12 rule of voting).

title: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
year: 2022
section: SUSTAINABILITY AND SPREAD

Content:
The medication safety champions in individual wards are able to reinforce medication safety practices to their colleagues. Staff will comply with medication administration process when correct practices have been consistently highlighted to them.
The monthly SCH medication bulletins have been sharing the correct medication safety practices with all staff. Group Comms have adapted one of the SCH bulletins to an article for HealthXchange on the topic of “Do Not Crush medications”. This can enhance cross-learning at SingHealth.

section: DISCUSSION

Content:

**Answer:** The following are projects related to reducing inpatient falls:

- **PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM044_SCH - Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och**
  - Focuses on strategies to reduce patient falls within OCH.
  - Year of project implementation: 2022

- **PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM001_SKH - Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need**
  - Aims at reducing inpatient falls specifically related to toileting needs.
  - Year of project implementation: 2022

- **PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM052_SCH - Reduce Fall Rate Of All Patients At Skch To Less Than 0.99 Patient Fall Per 1000Patients**
  - Aims at reducing the overall fall rate to less than 0.99 patient falls per 1000 patients.
  - Year of project implementation: 2022

section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The workgroup has implemented the following interventions:
1. Established a high fall ward for patients with high fall risk.
2. Implemented a multidisciplinary communication board to communicate on patient’s mobility status.
3. Piloted tango commodes for use in OCH wards.
4. Introduced a monthly Falls Free Award and CEO award for wards with zero falls for 3 months.
5. Identified fall champions at each ward to reinforce the fall prevention practices to ground staff.
6. Placed signage on toilet doors and shower doors to remind staff and patients that patients should not be left alone in toilets.
7. Piloted TEMI robots to display fall prevention messages and videos to patients.
8. Conducted role play sessions post-fall incidents for learning purposes among nurses.

Content:

This was seen through reduced use of diapers and commodes as well as an increase in patient walking activity.||CHUNK 11 || SECTION: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM || TITLE: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls || YEAR: 2024 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_CO005 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

section: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM

Content:
“There is no time!” • Each 5 minutes spent on finding mobility status in SCM for each patient could easily add up to a significant amount of time. Time that nursing staff do not have. “Where is the information?” • Different physiotherapists write their mobility information in different areas of the notes. “Is my minimal assist the same as yours?” • Discrepancy in knowledge of patient’s current mobility status could potentially result in unsafe mobilization of patients thereby increasing risk of patient falls.||CHUNK 12 || SECTION: CONCLUSION || TITLE: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls || YEAR: 2024 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_CO005 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

Content:
Therefore, we conclude that mobility signage is a simple and effective communication tool between physiotherapists and ward staff allowing for patients to be mobilized with the correct level of assistance. With fast access to patient’s mobility status, there is quicker and safer decision-making by ward staff as the time saved can easily be up to 5 mins for each patient.||CHUNK 13 || SECTION: OUTCOME || TITLE: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls || YEAR: 2024 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_CO005 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

PROJECT TITLE: Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need (SHM_RM001)

source: SHM_RM001_SKH - Reducing inpatient falls related to toileting need.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:11:31.085003
project_code: SHM_RM001
hospital: SKH
title: Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
• Revision of Nasogastric (NG) Feeds Regime: Last NG feeds regime scheduled at 11pm instead of 12 midnight and feeding via NG tube moved to 8am from the original 6am-7am.
• Adjustment of nurses’ activity (to include elimination rounds): Night duty nurse to do Capillary Blood Glucose (CBG), bring ambulating patient to toilet, sit out of bed for gargle and breakfast. Morning duty nurse to assist in changing/turning bedbound patients and prepare for oral care and breakfast.
• Implementation of reminder card placed at nurses’ counter desktops and computer-on-wheels (COWs).||CHUNK 2 || SECTION: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM || TITLE: Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM001 || RELEVANCE: 0.9 || CONTENT: Metadata:

The projects related to reducing inpatient falls from the last three years are:

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM044_SCH - Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och (2022)
- Focuses on strategies to reduce patient falls within OCH hospital.
- Year of implementation: 2022
- Hospital: SCH

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM001_SKH - Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need (2022)
- Aims at reducing inpatient falls specifically related to toileting needs.
- Year of implementation: 2022
- Hospital: SKH

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls (2024)
- Focuses on encouraging safe mobilization in a pilot ward to reduce patient falls.
- Year of implementation: 2024
- Hospital: SKH

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM052_SCH - Reduce Fall Rate Of All Patients At Skch To Less Than 0.99 Patient Fall Per 1000Patients (2022)
- Aims to reduce the fall rate of all patients at SKCH hospital.
- Year of implementation: 2022
- Hospital: SCH

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_OP022_SKH - Adapting Cloud Based Platform For Real Time Updates (2022)
- Involves adapting a cloud-based platform for real-time updates to improve patient safety and reduce falls.
- Year of implementation: 2022
- Hospital: SKH

test_query: Get me the methods of the posters on falls
llm_output:
The methods for reducing inpatient falls across different projects include:

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM001_SKH - Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need**
- Identified delays or non-execution of elimination rounds due to nurses being occupied with other duties.
- Listed out existing nursing night duty schedules and procedures.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls**
- Designed mobility signage with patient functional mobility information and pictograms for transfers and walking aids.
- Briefed physiotherapists on how to fill out the mobility signage after a functional assessment.
- Orientated nurses in the pilot ward regarding the use of mobility signage and explained mobility terms during roll call.
- Conducted monthly follow-up surveys by ward staff and nursing students, collecting patient fall statistics from October 2022 to December 2022.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM044_SCH - Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och**
- Conducted a root cause analysis in June 2020 to identify factors leading to falls at OCH.

These methods aim to address various aspects of patient mobility and toileting needs, thereby reducing the risk of inpatient falls.

project_code: SHM_RM044
hospital: SCH
title: Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The workgroup has implemented the following interventions:
1. Established a high fall ward for patients with high fall risk.
2. Implemented a multidisciplinary communication board to communicate on patient’s mobility status.
3. Piloted tango commodes for use in OCH wards.
4. Introduced a monthly Falls Free Award and CEO award for wards with zero falls for 3 months.
5. Identified fall champions at each ward to reinforce the fall prevention practices to ground staff.
6. Placed signage on toilet doors and shower doors to remind staff and patients that patients should not be left alone in toilets.
7. Piloted TEMI robots to display fall prevention messages and videos to patients.
8. Conducted role play sessions post-fall incidents for learning purposes among nurses.
9. Organized Nurse-led Interprofessional Education (IPE) on managing dementia patients.||CHUNK 2 || SECTION: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM || TITLE: Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM001 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

test_query: Get me the methods and results of posters on falls
llm_output:
**Answer:** The methods and results related to reducing patient falls are detailed in several projects. For SHM_RM001_SKH, a reduction of 57% in falls related to toileting needs was achieved. In SHM_CO005_SKH, an 8% improvement in confidence levels regarding patient transfers and ambulation was observed post-implementation. Additionally, SHM_RM044_SCH reported reducing the OCH fall rate to 0.80 per 1,000 patient days from June 2020 to May 2021.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM001 SKH - Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need**
- Fall Rate Relating to Toileting Needs reduced by 57%.
- Baseline Avg. fall rate was 0.63, and the current avg. is 0.27.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_CO005 SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls**
- An 8% improvement in staff confidence regarding patient transfers and ambulation.
- Increased mobility and reduced use of diapers and commodes observed post-implementation.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM044 SCH - Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och**
- Fall rate reduced to 0.80 per 1,000 patient days from June 2020 to May 2021.
- Root cause analysis conducted in June 2020 to identify factors leading to falls at OCH.

Content:
Staff Patient

- Patient unfamiliar with hospital setup
- Patient is uncooperative

- All manpower engaged in their clinical duties
- No other staff available in the ward
- Unfamiliar with patient's profile

test_query: What are the projects that aim to bring down medication incident rate.
llm_output:
The projects aiming to reduce medication incident rates are:

PROJECT TITLE: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (OCH) - SHM_RM045_SCH
- Focuses on decreasing the number of medication incidents in OCH.
- Year of implementation: 2022

PROJECT TITLE: Reduce Medication Rate At Skch To Below 0.3 Per 1000 Patient Days (Ch Average) Over 1Yr - SHM_RM053_SCH
- Aims to lower the medication incident rate at SKCH to below 0.3 per 1000 patient days over a one-year period.
- Year of implementation: 2022
retrieved_chunks:
CHUNK 1 || SECTION: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES || TITLE: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och) || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM045 || RELEVANCE: 0.9 || CONTENT: Metadata:
source: SHM_RM045_SCH - Reducing medication incident rate in Outram Community Hospital (OCH).pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:15:06.467446
project_code: SHM_RM045
hospital: SCH
title: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The project team brainstormed and came out with the following interventions:
1. A medication safety workgroup was formed to look into all medication safety related issues. Incidents were discussed with root cause analysis, and corrective actions were proposed at workgroup level.
2. SCH monthly medication safety bulletin has been published to share best practices and correct procedures to ensure medication safety.
3. Medication safety vest was piloted in selected OCH wards with the aim to reduce disruptions during medication administration. The intervention was not implemented due to unsatisfactory pilot results.
4. To implement a “status board” in SCM as a “live” board to keep staff updated on the list of tasks for patients.
5. Medication safety champions at each ward were identified to further reduce the risk of medication incidents. The champions will reinforce correct procedures to ground staff and create awareness. At the same time, they will communicate with their colleagues on new medication practices if any.
6. Complicated medications scheduling in SCM will be scheduled by the medical team, which will then be verified by pharmacists prior to nursing administration.||CHUNK 2 || SECTION: MISSION STATEMENT || TITLE: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och) || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM045 || RELEVANCE: 0.9 || CONTENT: Metadata:

title: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The project team brainstormed and came out with the following interventions:
1. A medication safety workgroup was formed to look into all medication safety related issues. Incidents were discussed with root cause analysis, and corrective actions were proposed at workgroup level.
2. SCH monthly medication safety bulletin has been published to share best practices and correct procedures to ensure medication safety.
3. Medication safety vest was piloted in selected OCH wards with the aim to reduce disruptions during medication administration. The intervention was not implemented due to unsatisfactory pilot results.
4. To implement a “status board” in SCM as a “live” board to keep staff updated on the list of tasks for patients.
5. Medication safety champions at each ward were identified to further reduce the risk of medication incidents. The champions will reinforce correct procedures to ground staff and create awareness. At the same time, they will communicate with their colleagues on new medication practices if any.
6. Complicated medications scheduling in SCM will be scheduled by the medical team, which will then be verified by pharmacists prior to nursing administration.

section: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS

Content:
Root Causes of Medication Events

| Root Cause                         | Percentage |
|------------------------------------|------------|
| Lack of awareness on medication safety        | 15%       |
| No / lack of proper handover practices during verification of medication order  | 13%      |
| Staff lack of knowledge             | 80%         |
| Lack of training or work instruction            | -          |
| Lack of system prompt               | -           |
| Insufficient guidance in cubicle (early morning)   | -        |

The workgroup conducted root cause analysis and identified the following root causes to focus on:

2. Lack of proper handover between nurses with regards to medication.

test_query: What methodology was used in successful projects that improved wait time perception at SKH Emergency Department?
llm_output:
The methodology used in the project "Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department" (SHM_PE023) included several initiatives aimed at improving patient and family member experiences, which likely contributed to better wait time perceptions. These initiatives involved structural and system enhancements such as an ED Patient Dashboard for real-time updates, SMS notifications for admission status, free-to-air TV entertainment, vending machines for refreshments, and reconfiguration of spaces for privacy.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_PE023 - Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department**
- Implemented structural enhancements such as an ED Patient Dashboard to provide near real-time updates on patient status.
- Enhanced the Supply Chain Management (SCM) system with a new column featuring flashing alerts for timely updates to Next of Kin (NOKs).
- Sent SMS notifications to update NOKs about admission statuses.
- Provided free-to-air TV entertainment and vending machines for hot/cold drinks and food to keep NOKs occupied during wait times.
- Reconfigured spaces, such as converting a grieving room into two separate areas to provide privacy and minimize interruptions.

These measures were designed to reduce stress and improve the overall experience of waiting family members, which can positively influence their perception of wait times.

- Hot and cold drinks/food vending machines
- Reconfigure grieving room into 2 separate areas to provide some privacy/minimise interruption for counseling of grieving NOKs as well as to keep the toilet/water dispenser available for both staff and NOKs
- Chairs with charging points to enable NOKs to use their mobile/laptop while waiting for updates||CHUNK 9 || SECTION: TITLE OF PROJECT || TITLE: Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_PE023 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

test_query: What methods were used in the fall prevention program?
llm_output:
The methods used in the fall prevention programs include:

- Establishing high fall wards for patients with a high risk of falling.
- Creating and distributing educational materials such as brochures, A3 mobility boards, abbreviation forms, and booklets to guide staff and educate patients and their Next of Kin (NOK) on fall prevention measures.
- Conducting regular assessments like postural blood pressure checks for new admissions.
- Implementing monthly nursing grand rounds focused on educating staff about fall prevention.
- Appointing fall champions in each ward to reinforce fall prevention practices among nurses.
- Introducing recognition awards, such as the Walk Steady Award and CEO Fall Free Award, to motivate wards with zero falls over consecutive months.
- Utilizing TEMI robots for displaying fall prevention messages and videos to patients.
- Conducting role play sessions post-fall incidents for learning purposes among nursing staff.
- Organizing interprofessional education (IPE) sessions led by nurses on managing dementia patients.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM052_SCH - Reduce Fall Rate Of All Patients At Skch To Less Than 0.99 Patient Fall Per 1000Patients**
- Established high fall wards for patients with a high risk of falling.
- Created and distributed educational materials such as brochures, A3 mobility boards, abbreviation forms, and booklets to guide staff and educate patients/NOK on fall prevention measures.
- Conducted regular assessments like postural blood pressure checks for new admissions.
- Implemented monthly nursing grand rounds focused on educating staff about fall prevention.
- Appointed fall champions in each ward to reinforce fall prevention practices among nurses.
- Introduced recognition awards, such as the Walk Steady Award and CEO Fall Free Award, to motivate wards with zero falls over consecutive months.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM044_SCH - Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och**
- Established a high fall ward for patients with a high risk of falling.
- Implemented a multidisciplinary communication board to communicate on patient’s mobility status.
- Piloted tango commodes and TEMI robots for use in OCH wards.
- Introduced monthly Falls Free Award and CEO award for wards with zero falls for 3 months.
- Identified fall champions at each ward to reinforce the fall prevention practices to ground staff.
- Placed signage on toilet doors and shower doors to remind staff and patients that patients should not be left alone in toilets.
- Conducted role play sessions post-fall incidents for learning purposes among nurses.
- Organized Nurse-led Interprofessional Education (IPE) on managing dementia patients.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls**
- Designed a mobility signage with concise information of patient’s functional mobility and pictograms of the transfers and walking aids to be hung at the patient’s bedside.
- Briefed physiotherapists on how to fill up mobility signage after functional assessment.
- Orientated nurses in pilot ward to mobility signage and explained the mobility terms used during their roll call.
- Conducted monthly follow-up surveys completed by ward staff and nursing students, and collected patient fall statistics during the period of the pilot study.

test_query: Compare the approaches used to reduce falls in SKH and OCH.
llm_output:
No relevant projects found in current documents for "OCH". The context provided only includes details about reducing patient falls at SKH (Singapore Khoo Teck Puat Hospital) through two main initiatives:

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization in a Pilot Ward to Reduce Patient Falls**
- Designed mobility signage system with visual aids for patients' functional mobility status.
- Trained physiotherapists and nurses on the use of mobility signage.
- Conducted monthly follow-up surveys from Oct 2022 to Dec 2022.

**PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM001_SKH - Reducing inpatient falls related to toileting need**
- Revised nasogastric (NG) feeds regime and adjusted nurses' activities to include elimination rounds.
- Implemented reminder cards at nurses’ counter desktops and computer-on-wheels (COWs).
- Adjusted nursing night duty schedules to ensure timely assistance for patient toileting needs.

section: BACKGROUND

Content:
OCH fall rate was 1.15 per 1000 patient days from Nov 2019 to Jun 2020. SCH management team expressed concerns over the high fall incident rate at OCH and had requested for a QI project to be conducted to establish appropriate interventions to reduce fall rate and ensure patient safety within a year.

section: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM

Content:
Root cause analysis was conducted in June 2020 and these root causes were identified:
- **Patient**: Poor self awareness and overestimation of own ability.
- **Staff**: Ramping up of wards during the COVID situation; changing of patient profile due to the pandemic.
- **Environment/Surroundings**: Physical layout of the wards, which contributed to blind spots as staff struggle to cover certain areas of the ward.
- **System**: Lack of training due to rapid ramp-up and the impact of COVID.

The members identified patient’s poor insight/overestimation of own ability and staff’s situational assessment as the primary causes of fall in OCH through voting.
