title: Enhanced Recovery After Thoracic Surgery(Erats)
year: 2022
section: OUTCOME

Content:
ERATS patients took an average of 2.77 days to achieve functional independence, which is 16% shorter than non-ERATS.

Quality improvement:
- Initial and repeat QoR-15 showed improvement in 94.5% of the patients.
- ERATS patients had a 9% higher improvement compared with non-ERATS patients.

Intangible benefits:
- Improved delivery of healthcare
- Adverts complications in patients’ recovery
- Earlier mobilization which allows earlier chest tubes removal, thus improving patients’ lung ventilation
- Increased confidence and independence for patients
- More time for physiotherapists to treat more patients
- Improved satisfaction among patients, Next of kin, and staff

source: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization in a Pilot Ward to Reduce Patient Falls.pdf

project_code: SHM_CO005
hospital: SKH
title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
Step 1: We designed a mobility signage with concise information of patient’s functional mobility and pictograms of the transfers and walking aids to be hung at the patient’s bedside:
Step 2: We briefed our Physiotherapists on how to fill up mobility signage after functional assessment.
Step 3: Orientated our nurses in pilot ward to mobility signage and explained the mobility terms used during their roll call.
Step 4: Monthly follow-up surveys completed by ward staff and nursing students, and collection of patient fall statistics during period of pilot study. (*Follow up surveys conducted every month from Oct 2022 to Dec 2022)||CHUNK 4 || SECTION: DISCUSSION || TITLE: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls || YEAR: 2024 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_CO005 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

hospital: SKH
title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: DISCUSSION

Content:
The mobility signage system helped improve confidence among staff in handling patient transfers and increased overall mobility among patients. Content:
“There is no time!” • Each 5 minutes spent on finding mobility status in SCM for each patient could easily add up to a significant amount of time. Time that nursing staff do not have. “Where is the information?” • Different physiotherapists write their mobility information in different areas of the notes. “Is my minimal assist the same as yours?” • Discrepancy in knowledge of patient’s current mobility status could potentially result in unsafe mobilization of patients thereby increasing risk of patient falls.||CHUNK 9 || SECTION: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES || TITLE: Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM001 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

project_code: SHM_RM001
hospital: SKH
title: Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
• Revision of Nasogastric (NG) Feeds Regime: Last NG feeds regime scheduled at 11pm instead of 12 midnight and feeding via NG tube moved to 8am from the original 6am-7am.
• Adjustment of nurses’ activity (to include elimination rounds): Night duty nurse to do Capillary Blood Glucose (CBG), bring ambulating patient to toilet, sit out of bed for gargle and breakfast. Morning duty nurse to assist in changing/turning bedbound patients and prepare for oral care and breakfast.
• Implementation of reminder card placed at nurses’ counter desktops and computer-on-wheels (COWs).||CHUNK 10 || SECTION: TITLE OF PROJECT || TITLE: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls || YEAR: 2024 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_CO005 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

chunk_1:
[section: CONCLUSION, project_code: SHM_CO005, year: 2024, hospital: SKH, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
source: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization in a Pilot Ward to Reduce Patient Falls.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T15:52:59.894244
project_code: SHM_CO005
hospital: SKH
title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: CONCLUSION

Content:
Therefore, we conclude that mobility signage is a simple and effective communication tool between physiotherapists and ward staff allowing for patients to be mobilized with the correct level of assistance. With fast access to patient’s mobility status, there is quicker and safer decision-making by ward staff as the time saved can easily be up to 5 mins for each patient.
chunk_2:
[section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES, project_code: SHM_CO005, year: 2024, hospital: SKH, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
source: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization in a Pilot Ward to Reduce Patient Falls.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T15:52:59.894244
project_code: SHM_CO005
hospital: SKH
title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The interventions involved designing a mobility signage system that clearly communicates the functional mobility status of patients with visual aids, training physiotherapists and nurses in its use, and conducting monthly follow-up surveys to monitor progress.
chunk_3:
[section: METHODOLOGY, project_code: SHM_CO005, year: 2024, hospital: SKH, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
source: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization in a Pilot Ward to Reduce Patient Falls.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T15:52:59.894244
project_code: SHM_CO005
hospital: SKH
title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
Step 1: We designed a mobility signage with concise information of patient’s functional mobility and pictograms of the transfers and walking aids to be hung at the patient’s bedside:
Step 2: We briefed our Physiotherapists on how to fill up mobility signage after functional assessment.
Step 3: Orientated our nurses in pilot ward to mobility signage and explained the mobility terms used during their roll call.
Step 4: Monthly follow-up surveys completed by ward staff and nursing students, and collection of patient fall statistics during period of pilot study. (*Follow up surveys conducted every month from Oct 2022 to Dec 2022)
chunk_4:
[section: DISCUSSION, project_code: SHM_CO005, year: 2024, hospital: SKH, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
source: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization in a Pilot Ward to Reduce Patient Falls.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T15:52:59.894244
project_code: SHM_CO005
hospital: SKH
title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: DISCUSSION

Content:
The mobility signage system helped improve confidence among staff in handling patient transfers and increased overall mobility among patients. This was seen through reduced use of diapers and commodes as well as an increase in patient walking activity.
chunk_5:
[section: INTRODUCTION, project_code: SHM_CO005, year: 2024, hospital: SKH, relevance: 0.6] Metadata:

project_code: SHM_CO005
hospital: SKH
title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: INTRODUCTION

Content:
We know that immobility during inpatient stay does not aid in a patient’s recovery. Between physiotherapists and nursing staff, we play a big part in getting the patient to move.

However, there is a breakdown in getting the mobility information from physiotherapy notes in Sunrise Clinical Manager (SCM) to the nurses.

Content:
Overall, response to implementation of signages were favorable. As the signages are easily administered at low-cost, there is interest to implement it to rest of SKH wards.

processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T15:52:59.894244
project_code: SHM_CO005
hospital: SKH
title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM

Content:
“There is no time!” • Each 5 minutes spent on finding mobility status in SCM for each patient could easily add up to a significant amount of time. Time that nursing staff do not have. “Where is the information?” • Different physiotherapists write their mobility information in different areas of the notes. “Is my minimal assist the same as yours?” • Discrepancy in knowledge of patient’s current mobility status could potentially result in unsafe mobilization of patients thereby increasing risk of patient falls.

[section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES, project_code: SHM_RM001, year: 2022, hospital: SKH, relevance: 0.6] Metadata:

project_code: SHM_RM001
hospital: SKH
title: Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
• Revision of Nasogastric (NG) Feeds Regime: Last NG feeds regime scheduled at 11pm instead of 12 midnight and feeding via NG tube moved to 8am from the original 6am-7am.
• Adjustment of nurses’ activity (to include elimination rounds): Night duty nurse to do Capillary Blood Glucose (CBG), bring ambulating patient to toilet, sit out of bed for gargle and breakfast. Morning duty nurse to assist in changing/turning bedbound patients and prepare for oral care and breakfast.
• Implementation of reminder card placed at nurses’ counter desktops and computer-on-wheels (COWs).

project_code: SHM_RM044
hospital: SCH
title: Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The workgroup has implemented the following interventions:
1. Established a high fall ward for patients with high fall risk.
2. Implemented a multidisciplinary communication board to communicate on patient’s mobility status.
3. Piloted tango commodes for use in OCH wards.
4. Introduced a monthly Falls Free Award and CEO award for wards with zero falls for 3 months.
5. Identified fall champions at each ward to reinforce the fall prevention practices to ground staff.
6. Placed signage on toilet doors and shower doors to remind staff and patients that patients should not be left alone in toilets.
7. Piloted TEMI robots to display fall prevention messages and videos to patients.
8. Conducted role play sessions post-fall incidents for learning purposes among nurses.
9. Organized Nurse-led Interprofessional Education (IPE) on managing dementia patients.||CHUNK 2 || SECTION: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM || TITLE: Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM001 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

Content:
The workgroup has implemented the following interventions:
1. Established a high fall ward for patients with high fall risk.
2. Implemented a multidisciplinary communication board to communicate on patient’s mobility status.
3. Piloted tango commodes for use in OCH wards.
4. Introduced a monthly Falls Free Award and CEO award for wards with zero falls for 3 months.
5. Identified fall champions at each ward to reinforce the fall prevention practices to ground staff.
6. Placed signage on toilet doors and shower doors to remind staff and patients that patients should not be left alone in toilets.
7. Piloted TEMI robots to display fall prevention messages and videos to patients.
8. Conducted role play sessions post-fall incidents for learning purposes among nurses.
9. Organized Nurse-led Interprofessional Education (IPE) on managing dementia patients.

From the responses, 67% of nursing staff reported reduction in use of diapers, 93% reduction in use of commodes and 86% of respondents were ambulating patients more often in the ward. With the mobility signage, my patients are using less diapers. N=42

processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:11:31.085003
project_code: SHM_RM001
hospital: SKH
title: Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
• Revision of Nasogastric (NG) Feeds Regime: Last NG feeds regime scheduled at 11pm instead of 12 midnight and feeding via NG tube moved to 8am from the original 6am-7am.
• Adjustment of nurses’ activity (to include elimination rounds): Night duty nurse to do Capillary Blood Glucose (CBG), bring ambulating patient to toilet, sit out of bed for gargle and breakfast. Morning duty nurse to assist in changing/turning bedbound patients and prepare for oral care and breakfast.
• Implementation of reminder card placed at nurses’ counter desktops and computer-on-wheels (COWs).

section: DISCUSSION

Content:
Members then listed out the existing nursing night duty and realized that elimination rounds were either delayed or not carried out due to nurses being occupied with other duties such as feeding patients via Nasogastric Tube (NGT) at 12 midnight, taking bloods at 6am - 7am.
